alt_statements.statement: As a progressive educator and administrator, I believe university leaders must protect students’ rights to peacefully protest on Israel/Gaza while drawing a firm line against harassment, intimidation, or discrimination of any kind. Administrators should create structured, well-facilitated forums for dialogue—much like we do in K–12 around difficult topics—grounded in clear conduct policies, trauma-informed support, and an emphasis on shared human dignity.

As someone who spends her days helping young people think critically and compassionately, I believe university administrators must protect students’ rights to protest while drawing a firm line against harassment, dehumanizing rhetoric, and any form of violence. They should create clear, consistently enforced guidelines that safeguard free expression for both pro-Palestinian and pro-Israeli voices, and pair that with facilitated dialogue and teach-ins that encourage real listening and learning rather than shouting past one another.

As someone who values both free speech and law and order, I think university administrators should allow peaceful demonstrations on Israel and Gaza, but draw a firm line at harassment, threats, or blocking others from getting to class or work. Campuses ought to be places where tough issues can be debated openly and respectfully, not turned into war zones or used to intimidate Jewish or Muslim students—or anyone else.

As a Jewish, liberal, health-focused person, I think university administrators need to protect free speech and the right to protest while drawing a very firm line at harassment, dehumanizing language, or anything that makes specific groups of students feel unsafe—whether they’re Jewish, Palestinian, Muslim, or anyone else. They should create clear, consistently enforced policies that distinguish between criticizing governments and targeting people, and they should actively facilitate structured dialogue and teach-ins so students learn to argue passionately but with basic respect and empathy.

As someone who values free expression and leans liberal, I think university administrators need to protect students’ rights to protest and speak out on Israel/Gaza, even when the message is uncomfortable, while drawing a clear, bright line at harassment, threats, or incitement to violence. They should apply rules consistently to all groups, avoid heavy-handed crackdowns, and instead create structured forums for dialogue where people can actually listen to each other rather than just shout past one another.

University administrators need to protect robust free expression and peaceful protest, while drawing a bright, consistently enforced line against harassment, doxxing, and threats toward any group of students, Jewish, Muslim, Israeli, Palestinian, or otherwise. They should create structured, facilitated forums for dialogue—backed by clear policies and consequences—so that students can confront hard truths, learn from each other, and organize for change without turning campus into a hostile environment.

University administrators should protect students’ rights to protest and speak freely about Israel and Gaza, while drawing a bright, consistently enforced line at harassment, threats, and discrimination—especially antisemitism and Islamophobia. They also have a responsibility to keep campuses physically safe and open for learning, which means setting clear, content-neutral rules about time, place, and manner of demonstrations, and communicating those rules transparently. As someone who values both justice and order, I’d expect administrators to facilitate difficult dialogue, not suppress it, but also to intervene quickly when activism crosses into targeted intimidation or disrupts core academic functions.

As a Jewish medical research scientist, I care deeply about both free inquiry and the safety and dignity of everyone on campus. University administrators should protect robust, even passionate, political expression about Israel and Gaza while drawing a clear, consistently enforced line against harassment, dehumanizing rhetoric, and disruptions that shut down teaching or research. They should respond with transparent policies grounded in evidence, civil rights law, and data on campus safety—not political pressure—while investing in facilitated dialogue and support services for students most directly affected.

As someone who has spent her life in the arts, I believe university administrators should protect peaceful protest as a vital form of expression while firmly preventing harassment, violence, and discrimination against any group—Jewish, Muslim, Palestinian, Israeli, or otherwise. They should create structured forums for dialogue, teach historical context, and listen closely to students on all sides, rather than rushing to criminalize or silence them.
